description.value: Connect to the administrative session of the remote computer.

descritpion.value: Do not use the administrative session.

description.value: Connect to the administrative session.
Determines whether desktop composition (needed for Aero) is permitted when you log on to the remote computer.
Disable desktop composition in the remote session.
Desktop composition is permitted.
Determines whether font smoothing may be used in the remote session.
Disable font smoothing in the remote session.
Font smoothing is permitted.
Specifies an alternate name or IP address of the remote computer that you want to connect to.
Specifies a program to be started automatically when you connect to a remote computer. The value should be a valid path to an executable file.
Determines how sounds captured (recorded) on the local computer are handled when you are connected to the remote computer.
Do not capture audio from the local computer.
Capture audio from the local computer and send to the remote computer.
Determines how sounds on a remote computer are handled when you are connected to the remote computer.
Play sounds on the local computer.
Play sounds on the remote computer.
Do not play sounds.
Determines the quality of the audio played in the remote session.
Dynamically adjust audio quality based on available bandwidth.
Always use medium audio quality.
Always use uncompressed audio quality.
Determines what should happen when server authentication fails.
If server authentication fails, connect without giving a warning.
If server authentication fails, do not connect.
If server authentication fails, show a warning and allow the user to connect or not.
Server authentication is not required.
Determines the maximum number of times the client computer will try to reconnect to the remote computer if the connection is dropped.
Determines whether the client computer will automatically try to reconnect to the remote computer if the connection is dropped.
Do not attempt to reconnect.
Attempt to reconnect.
Enables the option for automatic detection of the network type. Used in conjunction with networkautodetect. Also see connection type.
Do not enable the option for automatic network detection.
Enable the option for automatic network detection.
Determines whether bitmaps are cached on the local computer (disk-based cache). Bitmap caching can improve the performance of your remote session.
Do not cache bitmaps.
Cache bitmaps.
Specifies the size in kilobytes of the memory-based bitmap cache. The maximum value is 32000.
Determines whether the connection should use bulk compression.
Do not use bulk compression.
Use bulk compression.
Connect to the console session of the remote computer.
Connect to a normal session.
Connect to the console screen.
Specifies pre-defined performance settings for the Remote Desktop session.
Modem (56 Kbps).
Low-speed broadband (256 Kbps – 2 Mbps).
Satellite (2 Mbps – 16 Mbps with high latency).
High-speed broadband (2 Mbps – 10 Mbps).
WAN (10 Mbps or higher with high latency).
LAN (10 Mbps or higher).
Automatic bandwidth detection. Requires Bandwidth Autodetect.

By itself, this setting does nothing. When selected in the RDC GUI, this option changes several performance related settings (themes, animation, font smoothing, etcetera). These separate settings always overrule the connection type setting.
The height (in pixels) of the remote session desktop.
Specifies pre-defined dimensions of the remote session desktop.
The width (in pixels) of the remote session desktop.
Determines which supported Plug and Play devices on the client computer will be redirected and available in the remote session.
Do not redirect any supported Plug and Play devices.
Redirect all supported Plug and Play devices, including ones that are connected later.
Redirect any supported Plug and Play devices that are connected later.

Determines whether you have to press CTRL+ALT+DELETE before entering credentials after you are connected to the remote computer. When disabled, this setting will also delay the autologin until the user has pressed CTRL+ALT+DELETE.
CTRL+ALT+DELETE is required before logging in.
CTRL+ALT+DELETE is not required. You can logon immediately.
Determines whether menus and windows can be displayed with animation effects in the remote session.
Menu and window animation is permitted.
No menu and window animation.
Determines whether themes are permitted when you log on to the remote computer.
Themes are permitted.
Disable theme in the remote session.
Determines whether the desktop background is displayed in the remote session.
Display the wallpaper.
Do not show any wallpaper.
Determines whether a new Terminal Server session is started with every launch of a RemoteApp to the same computer and with the same credentials.
Do not show the connection bar.
Show the connection bar.
Specifies whether the Remote Desktop client should check the remote computer for RemoteApp capabilities.
Check the remote computer for RemoteApp capabilities before logging in.
Do not check the remote computer for RemoteApp capabilities.
Determines whether the connection bar appears when you are in full screen mode.
Do not show the connection bar.
Show the connection bar.
Specifies the name of the domain of the user.
Determines which local disk drives on the client computer will be redirected and available in the remote session.
Do not redirect any drives.
Redirect all disk drives, including drives that are connected later.
Redirect any drives that are connected later.
Determines whether Remote Desktop will use CredSSP for authentication if it’s available.
Do not use CredSSP, even if the operating system supports it.
Use CredSSP, if the operating system supports it.
Determines whether SuperPan is enabled or disabled.
Do not use SuperPan. The remote session window is sized to the client window size.
Enable SuperPan. The remote session window is sized to the dimensions specified through Desktop Width and Desktop Height.
Specifies the name or IP address (and optional port) of the remote computer that you want to connect to.
Specifies the credentials that should be used to validate the connection with the RD Gateway.
Ask for password (NTLM).
Use smart card.
Allow user to select later.
Specifies the hostname of the RD Gateway.
Determines the RD Gateway authentication method to be used.
Use the default profile mode, as specified by the administrator.
Use explicit settings.

Specifies if and how to use a Remote Desktop Gateway (RD Gateway) server. 0 and 4 have the same effect, but setting the method to 4 also sets the option for bypassing local addresses in the Remote Desktop user interface.
Do not use an RD Gateway server.
Always use an RD Gateway, even for local connections.
Use the RD Gateway if a direct connection cannot be made to the remote computer (i.e. bypass for local addresses).
Use the default RD Gateway settings.
Do not use an RD Gateway server.
Determines how Windows key combinations are applied when you are connected to a remote computer.
Windows key combinations are applied on the local computer.
Windows key combinations are applied on the remote computer.
Windows key combinations are applied in full-screen mode only.
Determines whether the level of security is negotiated or not.
Security layer negotiation is not enabled and the session is started by using Secure Sockets Layer (SSL).
Security layer negotiation is enabled and the session is started by using x.224 encryption.
Determines whether to use auomatic network bandwidth detection or not. Requires the option Bandwidth Autodetect to be set and correlates with connection type 7.
Use automatic network bandwitdh detection.
Do not use automatic network bandwitdh detection.
The user password
Determines whether or not the connection bar should be pinned to the top of the remote session upon connection when in full screen mode.
The connection bar should not be pinned to the top of the remote session.
The connection bar should be pinned to the top of the remote session.
Determines whether Remote Desktop Connection will prompt for credentials when connecting to a remote computer for which the credentials have been previously saved.
Remote Desktop will use the saved credentials and will not prompt for credentials.
Remote Desktop will prompt for credentials.
Determines whether Remote Desktop Connection will prompt for credentials when connecting to a server that does not support server authentication.
Remote Desktop will not prompt for credentials.
Remote Desktop will prompt for credentials.
When connecting through an RD Gateway, determines whether RDC should use the same credentials for both the RD Gateway and the remote computer.
Remote Desktop will not use the same credentials.
Remote Desktop will use the same credentials for both the RD gateway and the remote computer.
Determines whether Remote Desktop Connection will be started in public mode. This setting is incompatible with Autologin and some other features.
Remote Desktop will not start in public mode.
Remote Desktop will start in public mode and will not save any user data (credentials, bitmap cache, MRU) on the local machine.
Determines whether the clipboard on the client computer will be redirected and available in the remote session and vice versa.
Do not redirect the clipboard.
Redirect the clipboard.
Determines whether the COM (serial) ports on the client computer will be redirected and available in the remote session.
The COM ports on the local computer are not available in the remote session.
The COM ports on the local computer are available in the remote session.
Determines whether DirectX will be enabled for the remote session.
Do not enable DirectX rendering.
Enable DirectX rendering in the remote session.
Determines whether local disk drives on the client computer will be redirected and available in the remote session. This setting is replaced by Drives to Redirect from RDC 6.0 onward.
The drives on the local computer are not available in the remote session.
The drives on the local computer are available in the remote session.
Determines whether Microsoft Point of Service (POS) for .NET devices connected to the client computer will be redirected and available in the remote session.
The POS devices from the local computer are not available in the remote session.
The POS devices from the local computer are available in the remote session.
Determines whether printers configured on the client computer will be redirected and available in the remote session.
The printers on the local computer are not available in the remote session.
The printers on the local computer are available in the remote session.
Determines whether smart card devices on the client computer will be redirected and available in the remote session.
The smart card device on the local computer is not available in the remote session.
The smart card device on the local computer is available in the remote session.
Optional command line parameters for the Remote Application.
Specifies a file to be opened on the remote computer by the RemoteApp. For local files to be opened, you must also enable drive redirection for (at least) the source drive.
Determines whether environment variables contained in the RemoteApp command line parameter should be expanded locally or remotely.
Environment variables should be expanded to the values of the local computer.
Environment variables should be expanded on the remote computer to the values of the remote computer.
Determines whether environment variables contained in the RemoteApp working directory parameter should be expanded locally or remotely.
Environment variables should be expanded to the values of the local computer.
Environment variables should be expanded on the remote computer to the values of the remote computer.

Specifies the file name of an icon file to be displayed in the Remote Desktop interface while starting the RemoteApp. By default RDC will show the standard Remote Desktop icon. Only .ico files are supported.
Specifies the name of the RemoteApp in the Remote Desktop interface while starting the Remote Application.
Determines whether a RemoteApp shoud be launched when connecting to the remote computer.
Use a normal session and do not start a RemoteApp.
Connect and launch a RemoteApp.
Specifies the alias or executable name of the Remote Application.
Determines whether the remote session window appears full screen when you connect to the remote computer.
The remote session will appear in a window.
The remote session will appear full screen.
Defines an alternate default port for the Remote Desktop connection. Will be overruled by any port number appended to the server name.
Determines the color depth (in bits) on the remote computer when you connect.
256 colors (8 bit).
High color (15 bit).
High color (16 bit).
True color (24 bit).
Highest quality (32 bit).
The working directory on the remote computer to be used if an alternate shell is specified.
Determines whether the client computer should scale the content on the remote computer to fit the window size of the client computer when the window is resized.
The client window display will not be scaled when resized.
The client window display will be scaled when resized.

Determines whether the remote session window will be spanned across multiple monitors when you connect to the remote computer. When using Remote Desktop Connection 7 (Windows 7/2008), the Use Multimon setting is recommended.
Monitor spanning is not enabled.
Monitor spanning is enabled.
Specifies the number of pixels that the screen view scrolls in a given direction for every pixel of mouse movement by the client when in SuperPan mode.
Monitor spanning is not enabled.
Monitor spanning is enabled.

Determines which supported RemoteFX USB devices on the client computer will be redirected and available in the remote session when you connect to a remote session that supports RemoteFX USB redirection.
Do not redirect any supported RemoteFX USB devices.
Redirect all supported RemoteFX USB devices for redirection that are not redirected by high-level redirection mechanisms.
Redirect the supported RemoteFX USB device specified by the given instance ID.
Do not redirect the supported RemoteFX USB device specified by the given instance ID, even if the device is in a device setup class that is redirected.
Determines whether the session should use true multiple monitor support when connecting to the remote computer.
Do not enable multiple monitor support.
Enable multiple monitor support.
Specifies the name of the user account that will be used to log on to the remote computer.
Determines whether RDC will use RDP efficient multimedia streaming for video playback.
Do not use RDP efficient multimedia streaming for video playback.
Use RDP efficient multimedia streaming for video playback when possible.
Specifies the position and dimensions of the session window on the client computer.
